title: BC-APFN-Business News Digest
text: Business News at 2 p.m. Supervisors: 6 a.m.-5 p.m. Skip Wollenberg and Michael A. Lee. 5 p.m.-9 p.m. Richard Jacobsen. For help please call: 800-845-8450, ext. 1680. Photos, ext. 1900. For graphics and interactives, ext. 7636. Expanded AP content can be obtained from http://www.apexchange.com. For access to AP Exchange and other technical issues, contact customersupport@ap.org or call 877-836-9477. If you have questions about transmission of financial market listings, please call 800-3AP-STOX. A selection of top photos can be found at: http://bit.ly/APTopPhotos All times EDT. TOP STORIES: FINANCIAL MARKETS NEW YORK — U.S. stocks move sharply higher as investors take advantage of this week's big sell-off to add to their holdings. The stock market is rebounding from a sharp sell-off earlier that was triggered by concerns about the health of the Chinese economy. By Alex Veiga. SENT: 700 words. UPCOMING: 700 words by 5 p.m. With: — FINANCIAL MARKETS-PSYCHIATRIST-Q&A — After the convulsions in financial markets over the past week, emotions are running high for many investors anxious about their retirement accounts. Wall Street firms seeking to better understand the mindset of investors turn to psychiatrist Richard Petersen, who was warning long before the market correction that fear was creeping in and a rough patch was on the horizon. By Matthew Craft. UPCOMING: 600 words by 3 p.m. And: ECONOMY-GDP WASHINGTON — The Commerce Department issues the second of three estimates of how the U.S. economy performed in the April-June quarter. It staged a far bigger rebound during the period than first thought, pulling further ahead of the rest of the developed world as it grapples with the latest set of global headwinds. By Martin Crutsinger. SENT: 750 words, photo. TWITTER-LURING USERS NEW YORK — Twitter's most urgent task is naming a new CEO. But the most formidable one is convincing enough people that its service is essential, easy to use and not just meant for celebrities, 16-year-olds and news junkies. By Barbara Ortutay. SENT: 150 words. UPCOMING: Will be updated. 1 of 5
